heuristics.name: Visibility of system status
heuristics.description: The design should always keep users informed about what is going on, through appropriate feedback within a reasonable amount of time.
evaluation_criteria: Are there loading indicators when data is being fetched?
Do buttons show pressed/active states?
Is there feedback for user actions (e.g., success messages)?
Are there progress indicators for multi-step processes?

heuristics.name: Match between system and real world
heuristics.description: The design should speak the users' language. Use words, phrases, and concepts familiar to the user, rather than internal jargon.
evaluation_criteria: Are icons recognizable and standard?
Is the language clear and user-friendly?
Do labels match user expectations?

heuristics.name: User control and freedom
heuristics.description: Users often perform actions by mistake. They need a clearly marked 'emergency exit' to leave the unwanted action without having to go through an extended process.
evaluation_criteria: Is there a clear way to go back or cancel?
Can users undo destructive actions?
Is navigation intuitive and reversible?

heuristics.name: Consistency and standards
heuristics.description: Users should not have to wonder whether different words, situations, or actions mean the same thing. Follow platform and industry conventions.
evaluation_criteria: Are UI elements consistent throughout?
Do similar actions look similar?
Is text casing consistent?
Are colors used consistently for similar actions?

heuristics.name: Error prevention
heuristics.description: Good error messages are important, but the best designs carefully prevent problems from occurring in the first place.
evaluation_criteria: Are there confirmations for destructive actions?
Is input validation present?
Are error-prone actions made difficult to trigger accidentally?

heuristics.name: Recognition rather than recall
heuristics.description: Minimize the user's memory load by making elements, actions, and options visible. The user should not have to remember information from one part of the interface to another.
evaluation_criteria: Are navigation options clearly labeled?
Is important information always visible?
Are there helpful defaults or suggestions?

heuristics.name: Flexibility and efficiency of use
heuristics.description: Shortcuts—hidden from novice users—may speed up the interaction for the expert user so that the design can cater to both inexperienced and experienced users.
evaluation_criteria: Are there shortcuts for common actions?
Can power users work more efficiently?
Are advanced features accessible but not intrusive?

heuristics.name: Aesthetic and minimalist design
heuristics.description: Interfaces should not contain information that is irrelevant or rarely needed. Every extra unit of information competes with the relevant units of information.
evaluation_criteria: Is the interface clean and uncluttered?
Is there adequate white space?
Are only essential elements visible?
Is the visual hierarchy clear?

heuristics.name: Help users recognize, diagnose, and recover from errors
heuristics.description: Error messages should be expressed in plain language, precisely indicate the problem, and constructively suggest a solution.
mobile_considerations: Clear error messages in user language
Specific guidance on how to fix errors
evaluation_criteria: Are error messages clear and helpful?
Do errors explain what went wrong?
Are solutions suggested for errors?

heuristics.name: Help and documentation
heuristics.description: It's best if the system doesn't need any additional explanation. However, it may be necessary to provide documentation to help users understand how to complete their tasks.
mobile_considerations: FAQ or help section easily accessible
evaluation_criteria: Is help easily accessible when needed?
Is there onboarding for first-time users?
Are tooltips or hints available for complex features?

guidelines: Minimum touch target size: 44x44 points (iOS) or 48x48 dp (Android)
Adequate spacing between touchable elements (8dp minimum)
Primary actions should be easily reachable with thumb
Sufficient contrast ratio (4.5:1 for normal text, 3:1 for large text)
Line height of 1.5x font size for readability
WCAG AA compliance for text contrast
Don't rely on color alone to convey information
Bottom navigation for primary destinations (Android), Tab bar (iOS)
Appropriate keyboard types for input fields
Clear labels for all input fields

critical.description: Prevents users from completing core tasks. Must be fixed immediately.

high.description: Major usability problem. Significantly impacts user experience.

medium.description: Moderate usability issue. Causes frustration but has workarounds.

low.description: Minor usability issue. Cosmetic or minor inconvenience.
